comments.body: Good catch üëç
Was the previous type too strict?

Yes, the `elem?: ElementHandle` part is incorrect.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/404765/31690263-d6c3b93a-b357-11e7-9180-d52fb4b5351d.png)

The `args` that will be passed to `pageFunction` are of type `Serializable|ElementHandle`.

`Serializable` is an `any` and the previous code locked it to only `ElementHandle`

It also returns a `Serializable` / `any`

https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer/blob/v0.12.0/docs/api.md#pageevaluatepagefunction-args
I can't find any place where these are used. Perhaps this was a leftover of something else?

The `BrowserEvents` have the same purpose as the `PageEvents`, they are just references to available events in the `Browser` and `Page` classes. They can be used to make dynamic event handlers.

Technically, neither type is required, I just kept the code standard from the previous version.
Makes sense. :+1:
The [docs](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer/blob/master/docs/api.md#class-browser) don't mention an `on()`-method. Perhaps their document is outdated, or this doesn't exist.

The docs mention the events (disconnected, targetchanged, targetcreated and the targetdestroyed). The `Browser` class [extends](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer/blob/master/lib/Browser.js#L21) the [EventEmitter](https://nodejs.org/api/events.html) that has the `on` method.

I think we should be fine.
You're right, thanks for clearing this up! Just had a look at the source and it indeed does extend event emitter. :radar:

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +1030,1034 @@/** A Browser is created when Puppeteer connects to a Chromium instance, either through puppeteer.launch or puppeteer.connect. */
export interface Browser {
  on<K extends keyof BrowserEventObj>(
    event: K,
    handler: (e: BrowserEventObj[K], ...args: any[]) => void

comments.body: Now that both `Frame` and `Page` have a `click` method we can finally remove the one for the `Page` class https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/25508/files#diff-26c1cae70a0e01ff10cdc4e82232b3eaL952
Done üëç
Actually this may be problematic when you pass an `ElementHandle` to `evaluate`'s args, because in the callback it will be an actual `HTMLElement` of the DOM.
Hmm, that's an interesting point. With conditional mapped types in ts2.8, would be easy to solve :) But that might be more trouble than it is worth.
That looks pretty solid! Though it is definitely up to @marvinhagemeister @cdeutsch @jwbay if they are interested in bumping the TS version to 2.8
@andnp I'm all for bumping TS version to 2.8 if it improves type-safety üëç

   */

    pageFunction: (...args: any[]) => T | Promise<T>,
    ...args: any[],

comments.body: This change seems like it was committed by accident. It just moves the functions around.

Thanks for the review! I moved these functions because they are [part of the Page class](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer/blob/3762de7b91bb85d2f1979d49152af79a92a06bbd/lib/Page.js#L635-L665) and don't exist on [Frames](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer/blob/3762de7b91bb85d2f1979d49152af79a92a06bbd/lib/FrameManager.js#L253).  Since they were introduced in 1.6, I thought it was kind of consistent to keep this fix in a single PR.
@slyrz ohh right, I totally missed that. Thanks for clearing it up :)
This interface is used for `goBack(options)` which doesn't have this property according to the  api docs: https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer/blob/v1.8.0/docs/api.md#pagegobackoptions
That's annoying, I will create a new interface then.
Can you confirm that the all properties must be present? Last time I checked the api docs where  a bit vague on that front.
All properties in `EmulateOptions` are optional already, so the `Partial` monad was redundant.
Why rename?

It was to align with the name used in the puppeteer source code: https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer/blob/v1.11.0/lib/Puppeteer.js#L32
https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer/blob/v1.11.0/lib/Launcher.js#L377

But I can revert it if you think it does not make sense.
`args` here should have value as well.
Or rather, the same type but without `JSHandle` and `Element` instead.
Hmm, I thought about that, but `JSHandle`s are not only handles for `Element`s, right? I could pass a `JSHandle` to a Regex, and then my `pageFunction` would be given the regex itself. Is that right?

It looks like you want to catch circular references but this actually won't do that. [Here is an example.](https://www.typescriptlang.org/play/index.html#src=type%20Serializable%20%3D%0D%0A%20%20%7C%20number%0D%0A%20%20%7C%20string%0D%0A%20%20%7C%20boolean%0D%0A%20%20%7C%20null%0D%0A%20%20%7C%20JSONArray%0D%0A%20%20%7C%20JSONObject%3B%0D%0Ainterface%20JSONArray%20extends%20Array%3CSerializable%3E%20%7B%20%7D%0D%0Ainterface%20JSONObject%20%7B%0D%0A%20%20%5Bkey%3A%20string%5D%3A%20Serializable%3B%0D%0A%7D%0D%0A%0D%0Avar%20x%3A%20JSONObject%20%3D%20%7B%7D%3B%0D%0Ax%5B%22x%22%5D%20%3D%20x%3B%0D%0AJSON.stringify(x)%3B)

Catching circular references would be great, but I'm not sure if the type system is actually powerful enough for that (aka, I don't know how to do it).

The goal of this `Serializable` is more to warn when an arg will not be correctly translated to JSON and back. For example, `RegExp`, `Date`, `Function`, etc.

The original impetus for this change was when I tried to pass an options object like `{ elem: JSHandle }` as an arg. This _contains_ a JSHandle, so I thought it would work. But it actually fails because it's neither Serializable nor a JSHandle. 

More info on exactly why JSHandles are allowed, but not nested JSHandles is in the source near this edit: https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer/pull/3591
Ahh ok I misread the linked github thread.
Can you move the interfaces above the functions, to keep the order of things.
@alvis ‚Äì¬†`waitForTimeout` is already in this PR.
